name: ZIConnect AI Platform

privacy.privacyCompliance: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)

description:
With Unicef Innovation Fund and Giga Project, our objective is to leverage the inclusion of young people to better education and more opportunities through internet connectivity.

We also apply Machine Learning techniques to build explainable models to predict connectivity at schools. To find the model(s) that will be implemented in our service we will invest in feature selection/engineering and we will also carry-on experiments with a number of possibilities ranging from classical models (Learners) as Decision Trees and SVM's to more recent ones, including Gradient Boosting Methods and Deep Learning.

sdgs.relevance: We are focused in spread the platform and studies around the world and essentially our initial journey is focused on Brazil. We are using information on school locations and jobs to predict connectivity and its impact on employability. The platform provides unique Brazil labor & education market information. In this project, our main goal is to build an innovative AI model to predict connectivity at the school level using jobs-related and education features with connectivity data.

sdgs.relevance:
SDG 4 (Quality Education): By promoting access to credible and truthful information, AletheiaFact.org supports educational quality and the provision of reliable knowledge, which is essential for informed learning and decision-making.

SDG 9 (Industry, Innovation, and Infrastructure): Crowdsourced fact-checking is an innovative approach to combating misinformation. By leveraging collective intelligence, the platform contributes to building resilient infrastructure for information verification.

SDG 16 (Peace, Justice, and Strong Institutions): Fact-checking and the promotion of truthful information are crucial for justice, peace, and the establishment of strong institutions. By combating misinformation, AletheiaFact.org helps in promoting informed civic participation and accountability.

SDG 17 (Partnerships for the Goals): Crowdsourced platforms like AletheiaFact.org demonstrate the power of collaborative efforts in achieving broader societal goals. By bringing together individuals to fact-check information, the platform fosters partnerships and community engagement towards achieving a more informed society.

userContent.contentManagementPolicy:
AletheiaFact explores the following governance model: Personalities, Claims, and Claim Reviews can only be added by users that were educated through workshops and courses and we ensure through the RBAC system. A Code of Conduct is enforced in the platform [1] to avoid inappropriate and illegal content. Only trained fact-check reviewers can approve and public fact-checking reports. Admins (AletheiaFact staff) are responsible for monitoring and can hide and remove content from the platform. Reporting for inappropriate or illegal conduct is encouraged through the email contact@aletheiafact.org and automated tooling is in the product road-map to make sure we can scale.

[1] https://aletheiafact.org/code-of-conduct

protectionFromHarassment.harassmentPolicy:
(1) https://aletheiafact.org/code-of-conduct; Users can report harassment in the platform through an open communication channel to the Community Engagement team which will act accordingly
(2) The only way of communication between 2 users is when a fact-checking report is rejected by a reviewer, the platform doesn't allow comments or messages between users inside it; the community engagement team oversees these interactions through monitoring in a dashboard and can act promptly by blocking harmful messages and remove the user privileges if needed.

bestPractices:
Software Development Life Cycle (SDLC): User stories; Change management using version control; Test driven development using automated tests; Continous Integration & Continous Deployment (CI/CD); Code review; Code refactoring; 12 Principles Behind Agile Manifesto; [1]

Architectural Design: Modularity and Maintainability; Reusability and Extensibility; Accountability & Non-repudiability; Security & Consented Access; Universal Access & Open APIs; Microservices architecture; SOLID principles of object oriented programming. We build on top of NestJS [2] which contribute to most of these principles alongside SonarCloud and security scan tools that allows to enforce the standards [3].

Software Architectural Styles: Monolith; Database-centric; Representational state transfer (REST); Component-based;

Cloud Computing: AWS [4] IaC with Terraform [4]

User Interface/ User Experience (UI /UX): Ant Design

Coding Styles & Standards: opinionated Prettier

[1] https://github.com/AletheiaFact/aletheia
[2] https://docs.aletheiafact.org/compodoc/index.html
[3] https://sonarcloud.io/organizations/aletheiafact/projects
[4] https://gitlab.com/aletheiafact/terraform-modules

name: Open Health Information Mediator

privacy.privacyCompliance: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and the South African Protection of Personal Information Act (POPIA)

description: The Open Health Information Mediator (OpenHIM) is a middleware component designed to ease interoperability between disparate information systems.

sdgs.relevance:
Goal: Facilitate sustainable and resilient infrastructure development in developing countries through enhanced financial, technological and technical support to African countries, least developed countries, landlocked developing countries and small island developing States by 2030.

The OpenHIM provides access to interoperability services as a key element of health information exchange as free and open source software that can be leveraged by low and middle income countries.

clearOwnership.clearOwnershipURL:
http://openhim.org/docs/introduction/about

The OpenHIM was initially developed by Jembi Health Systems in collaboration with the Health Architecture Laboratory ( HeAL) at the University of KwaZulu-Natal as part of the Rwanda Health Enterprise Architecture (RHEA) project, and formed the basis for Ryan Crichton’s Master's thesis “The Open Health Information Mediator: an Architecture for Enabling Interoperability in Low to Middle Income Countries”. The OpenHIM is a current reference technology for the interoperability layer of the OpenHIE (Open Health Information Exchange). It is supported through a number of implementation projects that drive its continuing development to meet real world needs.

documentation: Technical and user docs - http://openhim.org/docs/introduction/about

These feature are documented as part of the API specification: http://openhim.org/docs/api/introduction/welcome

openStandards: Centralised logging of all messages for auditing and reporting. This utilises ATNA and is compliant with international standards.

https://wiki.ohie.org/download/attachments/13926693/OpenHIE%20MomConnect%20Presentation_FINAL.pdf?api=v2

In addition the following best practices are followed:

* It's designed to be modular with separate frontend and backend components
* It's designed to be stateless for easy scalability

name: Jellow AAC Communicator

privacy.privacyCompliance:
REGULATION (EU) 2016/679 OF THE EUROPEAN PARLIAMENT AND OF THE COUNCIL of 27 April 2016, on the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data and on the free movement of such data, and repealing Directive 95/46/EC (General Data Protection Regulation) - https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=CELEX:32016R0679,

The Children’s Online Privacy Protection Act (COPPA) - https://www.ftc.gov/business-guidance/privacy-security/childrens-privacy

openAlternatives: Jellow AAC Communicator uses a Google TTS engine

a closed source component due to the superior and satisfactory performance it offers especially with the Indian language and voices. One of the open source TTS engines available for the Indian language is Hear2read (https://hear2read.org/) which we've tried recently. The core app function is to provide speech therapy

and speech training to children with disabilities using intuitive icons. There are also a few secondary services (especially Google dependencies) that maybe inside the app or used for internal developer analysis . None of these services are part of the core app features. The secondary services include: - Analytics: This dependency collects user non-PII app usages such as mostly used screen and most used category icons. These analytics data are not mandatory to the app's core function. - Database: The Firebase real-time DB service stores the non-PII user's first language selection

and screen usage time only. These data points are again not mandatory to the app's core function. -Auth: To make the above-mentioned data write protect the auth service is incorporated. If the database part is not considered mandatory then this auth service is eliminated automatically. -Notification: The notification service to date is only configured to notify users about new version availability. This too does not relate to the core function of the app. - Storage: The storage service stores language content for the app. This language content can be moved to other storage spaces like Github or another storage hosting with little changes.

name: Energy Access Explorer

privacy.privacyCompliance: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)

description:
Challenge

Energy services are highly interconnected with socio-economic development and human well-being. Yet, life without reliable energy is a reality for more than 675 million people globally. Effectively expanding energy access requires proper energy planning and access to transparent analytical tools and data. To help address this challenge, WRI, in collaboration with partners has developed the Energy Access Explorer (EAE), a data-driven, integrated and inclusive approach to achieving universal access to energy for equitable, socio-economic development.

What is EAE? 
The first, open-source, online and interactive geospatial platform that enables energy planners, clean energy entrepreneurs, donors, and development institutions to identify high-priority areas for energy access interventions. EAE functions also as a dynamic information system, reducing software engineering and data transaction costs for both data providers and users and facilitating data management and governance.

sdgs.relevance: EAE provides geospatial data and analytics necessary to create a future where all people and institutions have access to affordable, reliable and modern energy (SDG7).

description: Radioship is an open-source language model engine designed to facilitate speech-to-text conversion for under-explored languages. It utilizes the language corpora from Mozilla Common Voice, an open-ai project that supports linguistic diversity.

sdgs.relevance:
SDG4 and SDG10: Radioship contributes to SDG4 by enhancing the accessibility of audio content in lesser-known languages through transcription, making it easier for people to understand and learn from diverse linguistic resources. Additionally, our speech-to-text technology supports SDG10 by breaking barriers and ensuring inclusivity. By making vast audio archives, such as radio broadcasts, searchable, we unveil valuable hidden content, promoting cultural understanding and diversity.

SDG17: Radioship aims to foster global collaborations among community radios. Our open-source speech-to-text tool facilitates audio archive searches, encouraging partnerships and knowledge sharing. By enabling community radios worldwide to use our technology, we promote SDG17's goal of strengthening partnerships for sustainable development.

sdg: SDG8: Decent Work and Economic Growth
sdgs.relevance:
Dalgo supports the social sector statistical capacity building in the nonprofits that use it. Our current nonprofit users work in the fields of water quality (SDG 6), early childhood education, K-12 education (SDG 4), vocational education, 21st-century skills (SDG 8), sanitation rights, and child and maternal health (SDG 3). By way of consolidation of intervention data collected from different sources, we enable nonprofits to generate holistic insights on their impact in these fields which inform their practice and communication of their impact. 

In line with SDG 9 target 9B - Support domestic technology development and industrial diversification: Dalgo also enables nonprofits to bring relevance to public data through the automated ingestion and processing of data from public data sources which is then made conveniently accessible to beneficiaries via on-ground or digital intervention (WhatsApp chatbots/webapps).

dataPrivacySecurity.collectsPII: PII data is collected and stored but NOT distributed.
typesOfPIIDataCollected:
PII collected depends on the organisation that chooses to collect information. Some organisations use Avni to collect health information of users in order to provide primary care while others that enable providing social security require PII for performing their services. 

Examples of data that organisations using Avni may collect - Name
dataPrivacySecurity.dataPrivacySecurity:
Privacy
Organisations are encouraged to ask for consent for providing information along with specifying the information being collected, the purpose and information about how it may be used. Many organisations choose to ask and collect consent in audio format. Some provide a text field that they read out and collect consent through an option in their mobile device. 

Security
Avni provides options to encrypt data in rest and transit, both within the server as well as in the mobile device. It uses OpenIdConnect (OIDC) for authentication and Role Based Access Control (RBAC) to control access to information to only those who require it. 

Avni has gone through a security audit to ensure the app follows OWASP guidelines.

userContent.contentManagement: Content is collected and stored but NOT distributed.
contentTypes: Avni allows organisations to configure forms that consist of text and numeric fields
multiple choice questions and image/video fields.
userContent.contentManagementPolicy:
Avni is used by members of an organisation to record information about beneficiaries. Collected content is usually meant to be used internally and not distributed to anyone outside the organisation. The organisation is the owner of the content. 

Most content involves text and numeric fields and multichoice questions. There is the option to add images/videos, which is used by some organisations. The expectation is that the user's contract with its organisation will ensure that inappropriate/illegal content is not stored by the user. 

Avni currently does not have mechanisms to identify inappropriate and illegal content, although there are third party mechanisms that can be used to scan and flag content in the object store.

protectionFromHarassment.harassmentPolicy:
Avni is used by members of an organisation to record information about beneficiaries. Direct beneficiary communication is not a core feature of Avni. The organisation is responsible for processes around protection of users and beneficiaries against grief, abuse and harassment. Having said that, there are some features that can help. 

1. There is a call masking feature that allows users to call beneficiaries without revealing their phone number. This helps protect users when they are working with a previously unknown group of beneficiaries
2. Avni provides mechanisms to integrate with Glific (an existing DPG), which can be used for two-way communication with beneficiaries. Grievance redressal mechanisms can be implemented on Glific.

bestPractices:
Storyboard - https://github.com/orgs/avniproject/projects/2. 
Code refactoring - Refactoring happens on stories where they are necessary

and cleanup happens when the developer is near the code. All code changes are reviewed.
Code review - We use a lightweight review mechanism and continue to push to the main branch on completion of a task. 


12Factor app (almost)
1. The codebase is in Github
2. Dependencies are mentioned through package.json or build.gradle
3. All config is maintained in /etc/ and read through apps
4. Backing services are declared through config
5. Separate build and deploy stages in CI
6. All processes are stateless (there is some cache
7. All services are accessed through service interfaces over HTTP
8. The process model is scalable through multiple VMs

and production use similar environments (differing only in size)

We've recently included mechanisms to use Avni through Docker so that deployments that use a containerized environment can use them.

organizations.name: Agrontology
organizations.contact_name: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Na

description: Agrontology is a description vocabulary defined in the Web Ontology Language (OWL) providing a set of domain-specific properties for agri-food concepts. It is used for instance in the AGROVOC thesaurus to express domain-specific relations between concepts.

sdg: SDG1: End Poverty in all its forms everywhere
sdgs.relevance: The Agrontology adds a semantic layer to any agri-food vocabulary (or dataset), providing domain-specific properties for concepts in the areas covered by the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO). Domain-specific semantic relations improve data and information exchange across repositories and institutions, which is essential to make and monitor progress towards the SDGs: in the case of the Agrontology, particularly the SDGs that have indicators for which FAO is the custodian UN agency. FAO is the custodian UN agency for 21 indicators and is a contributing agency to 5 more, spanning SDGs 1, 2, 5, 6, 12, 14 and 15.

openlicenses.openLicenseEvidenceURLs: Metadata in OWL file: http://aims.fao.org/aos/agrontology (property dcterms:license).

clearOwnership.clearOwnershipName: Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO)

documentation:
Documentation is included in the documentation about AGROVOC (see related DPG application).
In particular, in publications: FAO. 2023. AGROVOC 5: Using VocBench for AGROVOC curation. Rome: https://www.fao.org/3/cc3753en/cc3753en.pdf (from page 40).
For semantic technologies practitioners, the OWL definition file at http://aims.fao.org/aos/agrontology is self-explanatory.

In a nutshell, the Agrontology is an ontology "used to describe non-hierarchical relations between concepts: for example, 'irrigation' is practice for 'flooded rice' and influences 'soil salinization', while 'rain' causes 'lodging'. 'Lodging' causes 'crop losses', while 'fins' are used in 'locomotion'. These non-hierarchical relations express a notion of 'relatedness' between concepts. When applied correctly, these additional relationships provide more context and richness to the dataset" (source: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.compag.2020.105965). 

It is a living ontology, enriched and improved based on users' feedback.

NonPII.nonPIIAccessMechanism: Vocabulary information can be accessed through standard HTML website and downloaded as RDF/XML

openStandards: The Agrontology is a standard ontology definition file written in the Ontology Web Language (OWL)

openly accessible at a public URI (http://aims.fao.org/aos/agrontology#) resolved to an HTTP URL: http://aims.fao.org/aos/agrontology.
The file can be downloaded for local use or used directly by machines at that URL. 

OPEN PROTOCOLS:
a) HTTPS for download: evidence: http://aims.fao.org/aos/agrontology
---
OPEN STANDARDS:
a) RDF/XML: evidence: http://aims.fao.org/aos/agrontology
---
STANDARD LANGUAGES:
Beyond using standard and open protocols and formats
the Agrontology is expressed in the RDF "grammar". It uses a standard RDF vocabulary: the Ontology Web Language (OWL)

the W3C standard RDF vocabulary to describe ontologies. 
Evidence: the RDF serializations at http://aims.fao.org/aos/agrontology can be checked against the OWL scheme at http://www.w3.org/2002/07/owl#.

dataPrivacySecurity.collectsPII: PII data is NOT collected NOT stored and NOT distributed.

userContent.contentManagement: Content is collected stored and distributed.
userContent.contentManagementPolicy: Content in Agrontology is contributed by a network of editors who work for partner organizations and are screened and approved. Content submission is further moderated in an approval pipeline that ensures that any inappropriate content is detected and removed before publication. The tool used to guarantee an appropriate moderation workflow is the VocBench: https://vocbench.uniroma2.it/.

bestPractices:
The Agrontology adheres to the FAIR Principles (https://www.go-fair.org/fair-principles/) and the Linked Open Data design principles (https://www.w3.org/DesignIssues/LinkedData.html).

---
FAIR principles:
- Findable: the whole ontology and all properties have unique IDs (URIs) resolved to URLs and publicly available.
- Accessible: all (meta)data of the vocabulary are retrievable by their identifier (the URI) using a standardized

free communication protocol (HTTP) without authentication.
- Interoperable: (Meta)data about the vocabulary and the concepts use a formal
and broadly applicable language for knowledge representation: the RDF grammar and the Ontology Web Language (OWL)

which in turn implements the FAIR principles.
- Reusable: (Meta)data are richly described with a plurality of accurate and relevant attributes: the OWL vocabulary is designed to describe ontologies

and in addition the Agrontology uses the Vocabulary of a Friend (VOAF: http://purl.org/vocommons/voaf#) schema and Dublin Core for the metadata. Metadata contain a clear and accessible data usage license.
---
Linked Open Data (LOD) design principles:
- "Use URIs as names for things": The whole ontology and all properties are identified by URIs resolvable to URLs and publicly available.
- "Use HTTP URIs so that people can look up these names": all Agrontology URIs are resolved to URLs.
- "When someone looks up a URI
SPARQL)": when looking up a URI

the RDF response is returned.
- "Include links to other URIs so that they can discover more things": the Agrontology is not a value vocabulary
so does not include links to other resources
but it reuses URIs from other vocabularies (DCTERMS
deploymentCountriesDepartments: The AGROVOC thesaurus is the main "user" of the Agrontology
therefore the Agrontology is used by all the institutions that use AGROVOC

but it can be used by any other product. 
We do not have a list of all the institutions in the world that use AGROVOC and/or the Agrontology: they are open publicly accessible resources that can be reused without any kind of registration or authentication or acknowledgement. But we do know that many governmental bodies in FAO's areas of interest use AGROVOC and therefore the Agrontology. An example are the institutions that are part of the AGROVOC editorial network: the network includes government departments
Universities and Academies under the aegis of relevant Ministries from Argentina

name: IVTToken

privacy.privacyCompliance:
General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR),
Brazil's General Personal Data Protection Law (LGPD)
privacy.privacyComplianceURL:
https://github.com/investtools/ivttoken/blob/main/PRIVACY_POLICY.md

1. General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR):
   - How We Comply: 
     - Data Minimization and Purpose Limitation: We collect only the data necessary for our solution's functionality and clearly define its purpose, adhering to GDPR principles.
     - Consent and Rights of Data Subjects: We ensure that clear consent is obtained for data processing, and we uphold the rights of individuals to access, rectify, and erase their data.
     - Data Protection Measures: Robust security protocols are in place to safeguard personal data, including encryption, access controls, and regular security audits.
     - Data Processing Records: We maintain detailed records of data processing activities, ensuring transparency and accountability.

2. Brazil's General Personal Data Protection Law (LGPD):
   - How We Comply:
     - Legal Basis for Processing: We ensure there is a legal basis for processing personal data, whether through consent, compliance with a legal obligation, or other bases outlined in the LGPD.
     - Data Subject Rights: Similar to GDPR, we respect the rights of data subjects in Brazil, including the right to access, correct, and delete their personal data.
     - Transparency: Our data processing activities are conducted with full transparency, providing clear information to users about what data is collected and how it is used.

Compliance with these regulations is not just a legal requirement but also a commitment to our users' privacy and safety, especially considering the sensitive nature of data in the educational context.

description: This initiative connects underconnected schools to the internet through a blockchain model, rewarding ISPs and sponsors with connectivity tokens. Supported by UNICEF, it focuses on usability and scalability to enhance global educational access.

sdgs.relevance:
SDG 4: Quality Education
IVTToken directly contributes to achieving inclusive and equitable quality education by enhancing access to learning opportunities through internet connectivity. By connecting schools in under-connected areas, we are helping bridge the educational divide, aligning with SDG 4's targets of ensuring equal access to all levels of education and promoting lifelong learning opportunities.

SDG 9: Industry, Innovation, and Infrastructure
The use of blockchain technology in our solution supports the development of sustainable and resilient infrastructure, promoting inclusive and sustainable industrialization. This aligns with SDG 9's targets of building resilient infrastructure and fostering innovation, especially in terms of increasing access to information and communications technology.

SDG 17: Partnerships for the Goals
Our approach of collaborating with ISPs, governments, and international organizations exemplifies the spirit of SDG 17, which emphasizes the importance of multi-stakeholder partnerships. These collaborations are crucial for mobilizing and sharing knowledge, expertise, technology, and financial resources, all of which are essential for achieving all the SDGs.

documentation:
https://github.com/investtools/ivttoken/blob/main/docs/index.md,
https://investtools.github.io/ivttoken-project/

NonPII.nonPIIAccessMechanism:
Data Export Functionality in the User Interface:
Our platform includes a user interface feature that allows users to export non-PII data.
Formats: Users can export data in various non-proprietary formats such as CSV, XML, or JSON, depending on their needs. This feature is particularly useful for schools or educational authorities who wish to analyze connectivity data for reporting or decision-making purposes.

Blockchain Data Extraction:
Blockchain transaction data related to the connectivity tokens can be extracted directly from the blockchain.
Tools: Users can use blockchain explorers or similar tools to extract this data in non-proprietary formats. Given that blockchain data is inherently public and non-PII, it can be accessed and analyzed by anyone interested in the transactional dynamics of the token system.

openStandards:
ERC-20 (Ethereum Token Standard):
Adherence: Our connectivity tokens are based on the ERC-20 standard

ensuring compatibility with a wide range of Ethereum ecosystem tools and services.
Demonstration: Etherscan can be used to verify our token's compliance with ERC-20

as it lists ERC-20 token transactions and contracts. (https://github.com/investtools/ivttoken/blob/main/contracts/GigaToken.sol)

OpenZeppelin (Smart Contract Security):
Adherence: We use OpenZeppelin’s libraries for developing secure smart contracts

adhering to established best practices in contract security.
Demonstration: Our GitHub repository can be reviewed for the use of OpenZeppelin contracts. Additionally

our smart contract audit reports (available at https://github.com/solidproof/projects/blob/main/2023/Giga/SmartContract_Audit_Solidproof_Giga.pdf) validate this adherence.

JSON RPC API (Ethereum Node Communication):
Adherence: Our backend interacts with Ethereum nodes using the JSON RPC API standard

facilitating reliable communication with the blockchain.
Demonstration: Our API interactions can be validated through tools like Postman or Swagger

which can document and test JSON RPC API calls.

Web3.js / Ethers.js (Blockchain Interaction Libraries):
Adherence: Our client-side applications use Web3.js or Ethers.js libraries for interacting with the Ethereum blockchain

ensuring standard and secure communication.
Demonstration: The code within our GitHub repository demonstrates the use of these libraries.

HTTPS (Secure Data Transmission):
Adherence: All our web services use HTTPS for secure data transmission.
Demonstration: This can be verified by checking the SSL/TLS certificate on our website and services

visible in the browser address bar.

RESTful API (Application Programming Interface):
Adherence: Where applicable

promoting simplicity and statelessness.
Demonstration: API documentation hosted on platforms like Swagger can showcase adherence to RESTful principles.

dataPrivacySecurity.collectsPII: PII data is collected and stored but NOT distributed.
dataPrivacySecurity.dataPrivacySecurity:
1. Blockchain-Enhanced Security and Integrity:
Immutable Records: Utilizing blockchain technology ensures that once data is recorded, it cannot be altered or tampered with, maintaining data integrity.
Decentralized Nature: The decentralized nature of blockchain reduces the risk of data breaches commonly associated with centralized databases.

2. Data Minimization and Anonymity:
No Personal Data Collection: Our solution only collects non-PII data, which inherently reduces privacy risks.
Anonymity in Transactions: Users interact with the blockchain via wallet addresses, which do not reveal their personal identity.

3. Secure Data Transmission:
Encryption: All data transmitted over the internet is encrypted using modern encryption standards (such as TLS/SSL) to protect it from interception or tampering.
Secure APIs: The APIs used for data retrieval and interactions are secured with authentication and encryption.

4. Regular Security Audits and Penetration Testing:
Smart Contract Audits: Our smart contracts undergo regular security audits by reputable third-party firms to identify and rectify vulnerabilities.
Penetration Testing: We conduct periodic penetration testing to evaluate the security of our system against potential attacks.

5. Compliance with Data Protection Regulations:
Adherence to GDPR and Other Regulations: We ensure compliance with GDPR and other relevant data protection laws, even though we handle non-PII data.
Regular Legal Reviews: Our policies and practices undergo regular reviews to keep up with evolving data protection laws and standards.

6. Access Control and Authorization:
Role-Based Access Control (RBAC): Access to sensitive system components and data is strictly controlled and based on roles and responsibilities.
Authentication Protocols: We implement strong authentication protocols to ensure that only authorized personnel have access to administrative functions.

7. Data Storage and Management:
Secure Storage Solutions: Data is stored in secure, encrypted databases with access limited to authorized personnel.
Data Retention Policies: We have clear data retention policies to ensure that data is not kept longer than necessary.

8. Transparency and Accountability:
Open Source Code: Our codebase is open source, allowing for public scrutiny and contributions, which enhances transparency and trust.
Clear Privacy Policy: Our privacy policy clearly outlines our data practices, ensuring users are informed about how their data is handled.

9. User Education and Support:
Informative Resources: We provide resources and guides to educate users about data security and privacy.
Responsive Support: Our support team is trained to assist users with any privacy or security concerns.

description: Uwazi is an open-source web-based database application designed for human rights defenders to manage collections of information, including documents, evidence, cases and complaints.

sdg: SDG16: Peace¸ Justice and Strong Institutions
sdgs.relevance:
Uwazi has enabled many organisations to bring more efficiency and rigour to their work - and show how documentation can advance impactful human rights work. It has proven to be a successful foundation for a range of different uses, such as monitoring and tracking violations for advocacy purposes, case management for use in litigation, collective memorialisation to serve longer-term justice efforts, and advance access to information, such as the creation of human rights digital information libraries.

We collaborate with local activist groups, national human rights institutions, large international NGOs and many organisations in between. Some of our partners specialise in specific issues such as arbitrary arrest, freedom of expression, women's and girls’ rights, reducing inequality, historical memory, and transitional justice, while others focus on human rights-related mechanisms such as the United Nations Human Rights Treaty System. Beyond their shared commitment to dignity and freedom, our partners have an important thing in common: they achieve greater impact when human rights-related information is easy to access, navigate and understand.

name: cQube

privacy.privacyCompliance:
India Information Technology Act 2000,
General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)
privacy.privacyComplianceURL:
https://sunbird.org/privacy-policy

cQube is an open-source software available under MIT License. cQube software has implemented many best practices to keep user data safe and secure. The software has implemented data collection in an open and transparent manner cQube software implements principles of minimalism, transparency of data collection, and other best practices. cQube visualizations are accessible only to authorized users with log-in access. cQube implements capabilities in accordance with Indian Data protection law and IT Act and is compatible with other laws such as GDPR.,cQube, as open-source software, enables adopters to collect data in an open, transparent, and consented manner - store it safely & securely - and share it as per the data sharing laws of the country with the appropriate consent from users and in an anonymized manner. Adopters of cQube globally in different countries will be able to extend and configure it to comply with the various laws and regulations governing data privacy, protection, and sharing., As an open source-code solution, cQube will have to be viewed differently from hosted service/product solutions. While the source code is open, free, and available to all interested implementers/adopters (on GitHub), individual implementations may have their own view of how they may have addressed data management (PII/non-PII), hosting of the solution and so forth., Management of PII/non-PII data in cQube is pure as a “highly extensible/configurable/non-opinionated open-software solution”, and it’s source code lies in GitHub (cQube is not a ‘hosted service or product’). Implementers/adopters of cQube, have the autonomy to decide “what” fields to  capture/maintain, “what” other systems will they integrate with, “will” they share this data with other authorized parties (e.g. one Government sharing this dataset with other Government, or one Department sharing this dataset with other Department). While the cQube technical architecture has taken privacy and security controls into consideration as default implementation, it is up to the Implementers/Adopters to establish a privacy policy at their end to cover the various implementation scenarios (e.g. management & sharing of PII/non PII data).

description: cQube is an open-source platform for data-based insights. It allows for aggregated data to be visualized in a simple fashion, leading to insights and action. It provides flexibility and ease of use in creating dashboards, enabling business user to derive insights.

sdgs.relevance:
Saral can be used across domains for applications that require quick and seamless phygitization of data - capture of physical data in a digital, structured format. This results in significant savings in terms of time and effort that would otherwise be required in order to capture the physical data in a digital format. 

Sunbird Saral has been successfully used by the state government of the largest state in India (Uttar Pradesh) to conduct state-wide assessments tests for about 17 million students from grade 1 to grade 8 - in order to garner a grassroots level understanding of the learning gaps, as well as the needs and challenges faced by the students. 

The state had a strong desire to gain a deeper understanding of student performance in order to effectively cater to various programs and student learning needs, which aim to achieve universal foundational literacy and numeracy in primary schools by 2025.  However, traditional assessment methods bring forth several challenges - these methods were not at scale or student level, making it difficult to obtain reliable data for the state to make informed decisions. Additionally, the time it took for data to reach the central department from traditional assessment methods was too long, as the process involved physical question paper preparation, exam conduction, answer sheet evaluation, result generation and then manually digitizing results, leading to a delay of up to three to four months.

The Saral solution replaces the old answer sheets with OMR-based answer sheets and allows teachers to scan the answer sheet through the Saral App. This process instantly digitizes data and allows the state to receive digitized data on the very same day of scanning. Quick and detailed information provided by Saral Assessments has empowered decision-makers to make data-driven choices and take prompt action to enhance educational outcomes in the state.

The state is now also planning for a pilot program to explore the use of Saral for other teacher-led activities such as new student admissions to schools. The app can be used to quickly scan admission forms of students and transfer the data to the state backend systems, resulting in significant saving of time for the teachers.
